items.title: Fintech Ramp lands Eagles’ Saquon Barkley as investor and Super Bowl commercial star
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Saquon Barkley becomes an investor in fintech startup [Ramp](https://techcrunch.com/2024/04/17/ramp-raises-another-150-million-co-led-by-khosla-founders-fund-at-a-7-65b-valuation/) and stars in their Super Bowl commercial.
- Barkley initiated contact with Ramp after reading [Zero to One](https://www.amazon.com/Zero-One-Notes-Startups-Future/dp/0804139296) by Peter Thiel.
- The Super Bowl commercial features Barkley and was produced in just seven days.
- Ramp, founded in 2019, is valued at $7.65 billion and is known for corporate card and expense management services.
- This investment is Barkley’s largest private technology investment to date, alongside his previous investments in [Monad Labs](https://techcrunch.com/2023/02/14/monad-labs-raises-19m-to-grow-its-smart-contract-platform-and-improve-the-ethereum-space/) and others.
- The Super Bowl will take place on February 9, featuring the Eagles vs. the Kansas City Chiefs.

items.title: EU details which systems fall within AI Act’s scope
items.summary:
- The European Union has published guidance on defining AI systems under the AI Act.
- The risk-based framework regulating AI applications came into force last summer, with the first compliance deadline recently occurring.
- AI developers must determine if their software falls within the act’s scope to avoid fines of up to 7% of global annual turnover for breaches.
- The 13-page guidelines from the Commission are non-binding and subject to updates as the AI field evolves.
- The EU warns that there won't be exhaustive lists defining systems that fall within or outside the AI system definition.

items.title: Spyware maker Paragon terminates contract with Italian government: media reports
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- Paragon Solutions has terminated its contract with the Italian government after the company claimed the government violated agreed terms.
- This decision follows the disclosure by WhatsApp that Paragon's spyware was used to target journalists and activists.
- The Italian government denies any involvement with the spyware campaign and asserts that protected individuals were not targeted.
- Affected individuals include journalists critical of the government and activists opposing immigration policies.
- Paragon confirms it had to disconnect two Italian agencies from accessing its spyware product, Graphite.
- There are indications that victims of the spyware may be found in multiple European countries, not just Italy.

items.title: Mark Zuckerberg’s charity insists it’s not abandoning its DEI efforts
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Mark Zuckerberg’s charity, Chan Zuckerberg Initiative (CZI), reassured employees of its commitment to DEI despite Meta cutting its DEI programs.
- CZI’s HR leader Marck Gundacker emphasized that Meta and CZI operate independently, and Meta’s changes do not affect CZI.
- The organization, co-led by Zuckerberg and Priscilla Chan, has still made changes similar to Meta, such as layoffs and ending remote work policies.

items.title: GitHub Copilot brings mockups to life by generating code from images
items.author: Paul Sawers
items.summary:
- GitHub introduces Vision for Copilot, allowing users to generate code from images like screenshots and diagrams.
- New feature includes 'next edit suggestions' that predicts the next code edit based on recent edits.
- Copilot Edits graduates to general availability with new 'agent mode' for multi-file edits, aiming for more automation and intuitiveness in coding tasks.

items.title: RPLY is a new AI assistant that responds to missed texts
items.author: Molly Cantillon
items.summary:
- RPLY is a new Mac app aimed at helping users achieve 'inbox zero' on iMessage.
- The app uses AI to identify missed texts and suggests responses if messages go unreplied for over 24 hours.
- Created by Molly Cantillon, a Stanford dropout, RPLY is designed to reduce 'text debt' and improve genuine connections.
- It analyzes user text history to craft replies that match writing style and personality.
- RPLY includes features like filtering unanswered messages, displaying response statistics, and tracking inbox status.
- The app has attracted 1,000 paid users and targets professionals overwhelmed by messages.
- Privacy measures include a strict zero data retention policy and options for local processing on-device.
- Currently exclusive to macOS, with plans for potential future expansion to other platforms.

items.title: Keyboard maker suspends U.S. shipments over Trump tariffs on Chinese goods
items.summary:
- Qwertykeys suspends all U.S. product shipments due to new Trump administration tariffs.
- The decision follows a February 1 announcement of 10% tariffs on imported Chinese goods.
- All keyboards from China to the U.S. now subject to 45% tariffs at full value, replacing prior exemptions.
- DHL introduces a “tariff deposit” and a new $21 package processing fee affecting shipments.
- Qwertykeys is one of the first Chinese companies to halt shipments in response to these tariff increases, impacting smaller companies with tighter margins.

items.title: Flashes, a photo-sharing app for Bluesky, opens beta
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Flashes, an Instagram alternative on Bluesky, launched its beta for testers.
- The app supports photo posts of up to four images and videos of one minute.
- It filters Bluesky’s timeline to show posts with media, allowing users to switch between Bluesky feeds.
- Built by Sebastian Vogelsang, Flashes reuses code from his previous app, Skeets, which has over 30,000 users.
- As of now, Bluesky has nearly 31 million users and 1 billion posts.
- The beta faced technical issues but saw 3,500 sign-ups in the first hour.

items.title: Tinder revamps ‘Explore’ page to connect people with similar dating intentions
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Tinder updated its Explore page with new categories: “Non-Monogamy,” “Serious Dater,” “Short-Term Fun,” “Long-Term Partner,” and “New Friends.”
- New categories will help users find matches based on dating intentions and compete with Bumble BFF for friendship connections.
- Update ahead of Valentine’s Day aims to attract users looking for dates for the occasion.

items.title: OpenAI co-founder John Schulman leaves Anthropic after just five months
items.summary:
- John Schulman, co-founder of OpenAI, has left AI startup Anthropic after five months.
- He joined Anthropic in August 2024 to focus on AI alignment and hands-on technical work.
- Schulman's departure was confirmed by multiple reports; Anthropic's chief science officer expressed support for his decision.

items.title: Superlogic raises $13.7M at a $200M valuation to help consumers use reward points toward cool ‘experiences’
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Superlogic raised $13.7 million at a $200 million valuation to enhance the value of rewards points.
- The platform allows consumers to redeem points for unique experiences instead of traditional options like hotel stays.
- Partners include American Express, Mastercard, and Visa, managing inventory and payments.

items.title: Spotify, Warner Music Group sign new deal to help deliver ‘further paid subscription tiers’
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Spotify and Warner Music Group have signed a multi-year agreement covering recorded music and music publishing.
- The deal aims to create new fan experiences, enhance the music catalog, and introduce further paid subscription tiers.
- Spotify CEO Daniel Ek announced a forthcoming 'superfan' premium tier with additional features for subscribers.
- This agreement follows a similar recent deal between Spotify and Universal Music Group.
- The new partnership allows Spotify to attract more subscribers and boost revenue.
- It includes a direct licensing model with Warner Chappell Music, increasing the music ecosystem's value for artists and fans.
- Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

items.title: Mistral releases its AI assistant on iOS and Android
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- Mistral launches mobile app for its AI assistant Le Chat on [iOS](https://apps.apple.com/us/app/le-chat-by-mistral-ai/id6740410176) and [Android](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=ai.mistral.chat).
- Le Chat features a chatbot interface supporting queries, with recent updates adding web search, image generation, and a deal with Agence France-Presse.
- A new Pro tier subscription is introduced for $14.99/month, offering access to the highest-performing model and higher usage limits.
- Mistral claims Le Chat can answer up to 1,000 words per second and generates better images than competitors due to advanced models.

items.title: a16z stands by decision to hire Daniel Penny
items.summary:
- Andreessen Horowitz (a16z) defends its decision to hire Daniel Penny following backlash.
- Penny was acquitted for choking a homeless man during a subway incident and has no previous investment experience.
- He will work with a16z's American Dynamism team focusing on government and defense, with plans for investment training.

items.title: OpenAI launches data residency in Europe
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI launched data residency in Europe, enabling compliance with local data sovereignty for its products.
- Customers can now process data locally with zero data retention on OpenAI's servers for eligible endpoints and services like ChatGPT Enterprise.
- European regulatory scrutiny has increased following previous allegations of noncompliance, with investigations initiated by several countries including Italy and Germany.

items.title: Intel Capital fuels TrueFoundry’s $19M funding to help boost AI deployments at scale
items.author: Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- TrueFoundry, founded by former Meta engineers, raised $19 million led by Intel Capital to enhance AI deployments.
- The startup's software, available as a platform-as-a-service, offers tools for auto-scaling, maintenance, and monitoring of AI systems.
- TrueFoundry's customers, including NVIDIA and Siemens Healthineers, benefit from expedited AI platform launches and significant cost reductions.

items.title: Fizz brings on TikTok alum to help build out its marketplace and recommendation engine
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Fizz has hired David Vasquez, former TikTok head of creator monetization, as its new head of product. 
- Vasquez will enhance Fizz's recommendation system and expand its marketplace to include in-app payments and brand partnerships. 
- The platform has seen a 245% increase in daily posts and a 61% rise in daily active users, attributed partly to uncertainty around TikTok's future in the U.S.

items.title: Lyft’s new AI customer assistant is powered by Anthropic’s Claude
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Lyft has partnered with Anthropic to create an AI assistant for customer service inquiries.
- The assistant aims to efficiently handle initial customer interactions for both riders and drivers, significantly reducing resolution time by 87%.
- This partnership follows Uber's similar collaboration with OpenAI, highlighting the competitive nature of AI integration in ride-hailing services.
- Lyft's AI assistant uses Anthropic’s Claude, a large language model, to provide human-like responses and handle common support issues.
- Lyft's broader collaboration includes training and tools integration for its engineers to utilize AI in various processes.

items.title: Pendulum’s AI-driven platform helps enterprises better predict supply and demand
items.author: Becca
items.summary:
- Pendulum offers an AI-driven platform to help enterprises optimize supply and demand based on fragmented data sources.
- Co-founder Benjamin Fels emphasizes the importance of precise supply demand management for sustainability and profit.
- The company rebranded from Macro-Eyes before a funding round of $22 million, focusing on expansion and product enhancement.
- Notable customers include Adore Me and the U.S. Department of Defense.
- Jean-François Gagné joins as chief strategy and product officer, adding expertise from his background at Element AI.
- The company stands out due to its algorithmic approach developed over a decade, addressing the fragility of supply chains exacerbated by the pandemic.

items.title: You can now use ChatGPT web search without logging in
items.summary:
* OpenAI now allows users to access ChatGPT web search without logging in.
* Previously, only premium subscribers could use real-time queries like sports scores and news.
* The login requirement for using ChatGPT Search has been removed for the web version, but the mobile app still requires login.

items.title: IMI becomes the latest British engineering firm to be hacked
items.summary:
- British engineering company IMI disclosed a cybersecurity incident on February 6, 2025.
- The firm reported unauthorized access to its systems and is engaging external cybersecurity experts.
- IMI is complying with regulatory obligations but has not confirmed if any data was exfiltrated.
- This follows a recent incident involving rival firm Smiths Group, which also faced unauthorized network access.

items.title: Shein gets more questions from EU about DSA compliance
items.author: Natasha Lomas
items.summary:
- The EU has sent a new request for information (RFI) to Shein regarding compliance with the Digital Services Act (DSA).
- The RFI seeks detailed information on risks related to illegal content, transparency of recommender systems, and data access for researchers.
- Shein must respond by February 27; failure to comply could lead to penalties up to 6% of global turnover.
- Concerns regarding consumer protection, public health, and product safety in low-cost ecommerce are increasing.
- The EU has not yet issued any DSA fines, despite multiple investigations and requests for information to platforms like Shein and AliExpress.

items.title: Could this startup’s compact nuclear reactors revolutionize cancer detection?
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- Cancer rates are rising, increasing the demand for nuclear isotopes in medical settings.
- A startup, Astral Systems, is developing compact nuclear reactors using multistate fusion technology to enhance the supply of these isotopes.
- The company has secured over £4.5M in investment, aiming for better efficiency and lower costs than traditional reactors.
- Their approach is based on lattice confinement fusion, which achieves significantly higher fuel densities than conventional methods.
- Applications include safe hybrid nuclear energy, space exploration, and various industrial uses.
- Astral aims to decentralize production by placing reactors in hospitals or industrial sites, reducing reliance on centralized facilities.

items.title: India’s Zomato to rebrand as Eternal
items.summary:
- Zomato plans to rename itself as Eternal to reflect its expanding business portfolio.
- The change is motivated by the growth of its quick commerce unit, Blinkit, which has outpaced food delivery in significance.
- Blinkit could account for up to 70% of Zomato's value within a year.
- Founder Deepinder Goyal emphasizes the name change as a mission statement, with the Zomato app and brand remaining the same.
- The stock ticker will change from ZOMATO to ETERNAL.

items.title: Presto is building Stripe for EV charging
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Presto is an app created by Ashwin Dias and J.J. Raynor to help EV fleet drivers find reliable charging stations.
- The startup raised a $15 million seed round led by Union Square Ventures.
- Presto’s platform aims to connect fleets with diverse charging networks, facilitating smoother charging experiences.
- The app and API provide machine learning recommendations for finding suitable chargers.
- Early adopters include rental companies like Hertz and Avis, and Uber drivers looking for discounted charging options.
- Focus is currently on fleets, but discussions with major automakers have occurred.

items.title: First lab-grown meat treats go on sale in the UK — for dogs
items.summary: - Cultivated chicken doggie snacks are available at UK retailer Pets at Home. - These treats are produced by startup Meatly, which has a significant investment from Pets at Home. - The product, called The Pack’s Chick Bites, features slaughter-free, low carbon ingredients. - Meatly claims to be the first to retail cultivated meat for pet food, achieving regulatory approval last summer. - The initial release of these snacks is limited as production capacity is capped, but Meatly plans to scale up availability.

items.title: Comstruct, a platform to digitize the construction industry, raises $13.5 million
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- Munich-based startup Comstruct has raised $12.5 million in a Series A round led by GV and 20VC, with support from Booom and Puzzle Ventures.
- Comstruct aims to digitize the procurement process in construction, which is currently very analog, by unifying materials orders from multiple suppliers onto one platform.
- The platform has already integrated 800 material suppliers and covers 70-80% of requested suppliers in Switzerland, with plans to expand into Germany, Austria, and other countries.
- Comstruct has four modules for ordering, digital delivery receipts, invoice reconciliation, and ESG reporting, implementing usage-based pricing.

items.title: Avelios nabs $31M led by Sequoia to fix the ailing world of healthcare IT
items.author: Christian Albrecht, Nicolas Jakob, Sebastian Krammer
items.summary:
- Avelios, a Munich-based startup, raised €30 million ($31 million) in Series A funding, led by Sequoia.
- The funding will enhance their end-to-end administrative healthcare system, using AI and cloud services.
- Avelios has signed 12 customers, including major German hospitals, and is eyeing expansion into Spain, France, and the U.K.
- The company aims to replace outdated legacy hospital systems that have not been updated for decades.
- CEO Christian Albrecht highlights efficient growth from previous €5 million funding and a strong engineering team.
- Avelios seeks to address major issues within healthcare IT by creating integrated systems rather than piecemeal solutions.
- The investment round marks increasing investor interest in healthcare software solutions that adapt to the push for AI and modernization in the sector.

items.title: European VC firm Emblem raises $85 million for its initial fund
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- Emblem, a new European VC firm based in Paris, has closed its first fund with €80 million (around $85 million).
- The fund was completed 18 months after its initial closing despite a challenging funding environment, with European venture funding declining for the third consecutive year.
- Emblem has already invested in 16 startups since March 2023, focusing primarily on France and the Nordic tech ecosystem, with plans to lead or co-lead seed rounds ranging from €500,000 to €3 million.

items.title: Aiming to accelerate product design with AI, Trace.Space raises a seed round
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- Trace.Space, based in Riga, Latvia, has raised $4 million in seed funding to enhance product design using AI.
- The platform focuses on developing complex regulated products like electric vehicles, satellites, and medical devices via a cloud-based approach.
- Industry pressures from Asian manufacturers drive the need for modern AI-driven design tools.

items.title: Researchers Benchmark AI Reasoning Using NPR's Sunday Puzzle
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- NPR's Sunday Puzzle provides a unique benchmark for testing AI reasoning capabilities.
- Researchers from various colleges created a benchmark using around 600 riddles from the puzzle.
- AI models like OpenAI’s o1 and DeepSeek’s R1 were tested, revealing unexpected behaviors such as 'giving up' or providing incorrect answers.
- The best-performing model achieved a score of 59%, while higher reasoning effort models performed slightly lower.
- This study aims to create accessible reasoning benchmarks that don’t require advanced knowledge, promoting better understanding of AI capabilities.

items.title: Boston Dynamics joins forces with its former CEO to speed the learning of its Atlas humanoid robot
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Boston Dynamics announced a partnership with the Robotics & AI Institute to enhance reinforcement learning for its Atlas humanoid robot.
- The collaboration aims to improve learning efficiency using simulation-based techniques and trial-and-error methods similar to human learning.
- The initiative focuses on advancing Atlas's ability to perform complex tasks like dynamic running and full-body manipulation of heavy objects.
- Marc Raibert, former CEO of Boston Dynamics, leads the RAI Institute, which explores experimental robotics technologies funded by Hyundai.
- This partnership follows a recent collaboration with Toyota Research Institute to apply large behavior models to improve robotic capabilities.

items.title: SoftBank could soon buy Renee James’ Ampere chip company for about $6.5B
items.summary:
- Ampere, founded by former Intel exec Renee James, is reportedly selling to SoftBank for about $6.5 billion.
- This valuation is down from $8 billion in 2021 when SoftBank considered buying a minority stake.
- Ampere designs ARM chips for data centers, aligning well with SoftBank's ownership of ARM Holdings.
- Renee James founded Ampere in 2017 after leaving Intel and focused on low-energy ARM designs for data centers.
- Oracle disclosed it owns 29% of Ampere and has options for a controlling stake, possibly affecting the sale.

items.title: Sonos lays off 200 ahead of rumored set-top box release
items.author: Tom Conrad
items.summary:
- Sonos laid off 200 employees in February 2025, following a previous layoff of 100 in August 2024.
- The layoffs occur after a significant update to the Sonos app alienated many loyal customers.
- Interim CEO Tom Conrad cited communication issues stemming from the company's size as a reason for the layoffs.
- Sonos is preparing to release a new set-top box/home hub, codenamed 'Pinewood,' currently in beta testing, expected to launch in 2025 at a price range of $200 to $400.

items.title: Researchers created an open rival to OpenAI’s o1 ‘reasoning’ model for under $50
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- AI researchers from Stanford and the University of Washington trained an AI reasoning model called s1 for under $50 in cloud compute credits.
- s1 performs similarly to advanced models like OpenAI's o1 and DeepSeek's R1, excelling in math and coding tests.
- The model was distilled from Google's Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking Experimental and is available on [GitHub](https://github.com/simplescaling/s1).
- The training process involved creating a dataset of 1,000 curated questions and using supervised fine-tuning (SFT), which was cheaper than methods used by competitors.
- S1 achieved strong benchmark results after a training time of less than 30 minutes on 16 Nvidia H100 GPUs, with compute costs estimated at about $20.
- The investment in AI infrastructure from major companies like Meta, Google, and Microsoft is expected to reach hundreds of billions in 2025.

items.title: Scout Motors sued over plan to sell EVs direct to consumers
items.summary:
- Scout Motors plans to sell EVs directly to consumers instead of through traditional dealerships.
- A lawsuit filed by a group of Volkswagen and Audi dealers aims to block this direct-to-consumer sales model.
- The lawsuit follows previous efforts to hinder direct sales by EV startups like Tesla, with Scout expected to start production in 2027.
- The California New Car Dealers Association issued a cease-and-desist letter, claiming direct sales violate state law, with support from dealers in Florida and other states.

items.title: Bench burned through $135 million before shutting down
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Bench, a Canada-based startup, burned through $135 million from its founding in 2012 to September 2024 due to struggles with profitability.
- The company faced a liquidity crisis and shut down with only $800,000 in cash in Canada and less than $400,000 in the U.S.
- Despite efforts to cut losses, including reducing losses from $30 million on $42 million in revenue to nearly $15 million on $49 million in revenue, it was not enough to prevent bankruptcy.
- In June 2024, Bench's biggest lender, the National Bank of Canada, provided over $40 million in loans, but the startup ultimately failed just weeks later.
- NBC was owed $51 million by Bench, and a potential acquisition by Employer.com is planned for February 28, 2025.

items.title: A comprehensive list of 2024 and 2025 tech layoffs
items.summary:
- The tech layoff wave continued through 2024, with over 150,000 job cuts across 542 companies.
- Significant layoffs were reported at major companies including [Tesla](https://techcrunch.com/2024/04/15/tesla-layoffs-workers-sales-cybertruck-cuts/), [Amazon](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/10/amazon-prime-video-and-mgm-studios-laid-off-hundreds-of-employees/), [Google](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/10/google-cuts-hundreds-of-jobs-in-its-voice-assistance-hardware-teams-as-fitbit-founders-leave/), [TikTok](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/23/tiktok-lays-off-60-employees/), [Snap](https://techcrunch.com/2024/02/05/snapchats-parent-lays-off-10-of-workforce-in-order-to-reduce-hierarchy-says-company/), and [Microsoft](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/25/microsoft-lays-off-1900-employees-in-activision-blizzard-and-xbox-divisions/).
- Trends in layoffs will continue into 2025, with detailed tracking by [Layoffs.fyi](https://layoffs.fyi/).
- The layoffs highlight the impact of businesses shifting towards AI and automation, affecting both large companies and startups.

items.title: XOi raises $230M, acquires Specifx to expand its tech for field service technicians
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- XOi raised $230 million from KKR to expand its software solutions for field service technicians.
- The funds will be partially used to acquire Specifix, adding 85,000 model families to XOi's datasets for enhanced maintenance predictions.
- This acquisition makes KKR a majority owner of XOi, which has previously raised less than $20 million.

items.title: Google ditches DEI hiring goals
items.summary:
- Google eliminates its diversity hiring targets and will review its DEI programs.
- This decision follows a trend among tech companies to roll back DEI initiatives amid criticism from conservative groups.
- DEI targets were first introduced in 2009, with a goal set in 2020 to increase hires from underrepresented groups by 30%.
- Google's 2024 diversity report indicates minimal change in leadership demographics, maintaining 5.7% Black and 7.5% Latino representation.
- The company is also considering whether to continue publishing its diversity reports and adapting programs in response to recent legal changes.

items.title: The biggest breach of US government data is under way
items.summary:
[ Operatives working for Elon Musk have gained unprecedented access to U.S. government departments, including systems critical to millions of federal employees and $6 trillion in payments. ]
[ The Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) has taken control of sensitive datasets despite lack of clarity regarding security clearances and cybersecurity practices. ]
[ Concerns have been raised about the security of sensitive data following reports of improper handling and a possible national security risk due to Musk's private sector access. ]

items.title: Amazon reportedly gears up to release next-gen Alexa
items.summary:
- Amazon is set to preview a next-gen, AI-powered Alexa on February 26.
- The new Alexa can handle multiple commands in sequence, unlike the current version.
- Initially available for a limited number of free users, potential subscription fee of $5 to $10 is being considered.
- The classic version of Alexa will still be offered alongside the new version.
- Development faced challenges, including issues with timer functionalities.

items.title: Paragon spyware used to target citizens across Europe, says Italian government
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- The Italian government confirmed a spyware campaign targeting citizens in Europe using Paragon Solutions spyware.
- Notable individuals targeted include journalist Francesco Cancellato and activist Luca Casarini.
- The spyware campaign has affected users in Italy as well as several other European countries including Austria, Belgium, and Germany.
- WhatsApp reported that around 90 users in over two dozen countries were targeted in this campaign.
- Paragon Solutions stated it prohibits targeting of journalists and civil society figures and requires compliance with its terms of service.

items.title: Why IQ is a poor test for AI
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI CEO Sam Altman noted AI's rapid improvement in IQ over recent years, suggesting an increase of about one standard deviation of IQ annually.
- Experts criticize IQ as a misleading measure for AI capabilities, emphasizing that IQ tests are based on human intelligence criteria, which do not apply to AI.
- Sandra Wachter points out the biases and limitations of IQ tests, arguing they oversimplify human intelligence and can lead to incorrect assumptions about AI's capabilities.
- AI potentially has an advantage on IQ tests due to its ability to process and memorize vast amounts of information from training data.
- Experts call for the development of better testing measures for AI that account for its unique problem-solving approaches, as current IQ tests are designed primarily for human evaluation.

items.title: As GLP1s boom, dietician startups Berry Street, Fay each nab $50M rounds
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Berry Street raised a $50 million funding round from investors such as Northzone, Sofinova, and FJ Labs to support nutritional counseling platforms for dieticians.
- Fay matched independent dieticians with patients and also secured a $50 million Series B round led by Goldman Sachs, reaching a $500 million valuation.
- The growth of GLP-1 drugs, which assist in weight loss, is driving increased demand for nutritional therapy and dietician services, which are typically covered by insurance.

items.title: Ransomware payments dropped in 2024 as victims refused to pay hackers
items.summary:
- Ransomware payments fell by over 35% in 2024, totaling $814 million, down from $1.25 billion in 2023.
- The number of victims refusing to pay increased, with demands from hackers 53% higher than actual payments during the second half of 2024.
- The decline is attributed to increased law enforcement actions and better international collaboration against ransomware gangs.

items.title: Stripe makes $1.1 billion crypto bet as it closes on Bridge acquisition
items.summary:
- Stripe has completed a $1.1 billion acquisition of stablecoin platform Bridge on February 5, 2025.
- This acquisition marks Stripe's largest purchase to date and signifies a strong emphasis on the cryptocurrency market.
- Bridge, co-founded by Zach Abrams and Sean Yu, provides an API for companies to accept stablecoins and had previously raised $58 million with a valuation of $200 million in 2024.
- Patrick Collison, Stripe's CEO, noted the swift adoption of stablecoin technology, suggesting a widespread future need for stablecoin strategies in moving money.
- Last year, Stripe enabled crypto purchases in the EU and introduced a Pay with Crypto feature for merchants to accept stablecoins.

items.title: The Elon Musk Act aims to ban ‘special government employees’ from having federal contracts
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- U.S. Representative Mark Pocan introduces the ELON MUSK Act to prohibit 'special government employees' from federal contracts.
- The act aims to prevent conflicts of interest, particularly citing Elon Musk's significant federal contract history.
- Musk's involvement with federal agencies, including a controversial advisory role, raises concerns about ethical breaches and public influence.
- The bill coincides with protests and bipartisan legislative efforts to restrict Musk's access to government systems.

items.title: New target of Paragon spyware comes forward
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- Mediterranea Saving Humans announced one of its founders, Luca Casarini, was targeted by Paragon spyware.
- WhatsApp disrupted a campaign targeting around 90 individuals, including journalists and civil society members, using Paragon spyware.
- Other targets include journalist Francesco Cancellato and activist Husam El Gomati, all critical of the current Italian government.

items.title: Workday cuts nearly 2,000 employees
items.summary:
- Workday laid off 1,750 employees, about 8.5% of its workforce.
- CEO Carl Eschenbach stated the need for a new approach in the current market.
- The company plans to hire AI talent in the future.
- Other tech companies also announced recent layoffs, including Okta and Cruise.
